Mrs WICKS (Robertson) (10:02): I present 44 ministerial responses to peritions previously presented.
Thank you for your letter of 16 October 2017 regarding Petition Number EN0108 - Aviation Safety, presented to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions.
I have sought the advice of Australia's Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) on the drug and alcohol regulatory requirements for civil aviation and I can advise the following.

Under Part 99 of the Civil Aviation Safety Regulations 1998, all pilots engaged in accordance with an air operator's certificate, including pilots of commercial passenger flights, are subject to a Drug and Alcohol Management Plan (DAMP), managed by the airline operator and which includes a testing program. This testing is not conducted in public to protect the privacy of the pilots concerned.

An operator's DAMP is designed to educate their employees on the safe use of drugs and alcohol, and require DAMP supervisors to conduct drug or alcohol tests if there are reasonable grounds to believe that the employee may be adversely affected by a testable drug or alcohol while performing or available to perform duties as a pilot.

DAMPS are subject to audit, oversight and monitoring by CASA. Additionally, CASA also conducts its own random drug and alcohol tests of people involved in safety sensitive aviation activities, which includes pilots and co-pilots.
Further information on the DAMP scheme is available on CASA's website at www.casa.gov.au/safety-management/landing-page/drug-and-alcohol-management-plans.
Thank you again for taking the time to write to me on this matter.
from the Minister for Infrastructure and Transport, Mr Chester
Thank you for your correspondence concerning a petition to introduce a tax on sugar-sweetened drinks and to use the revenue to fund public health initiatives.

It is worth noting that Australia's goods and services tax (GST) system already favours nutritional food through GST-free treatment. Many basic foods such as fruit and vegetables, meat, eggs, bread and milk have been GST-free since the introduction of the GST in 2000, while items such as soft drinks, confectionary and biscuits are taxed.

The Government is concerned about the increasing rate of obesity and decline in physical activity and good eating among Australians. Nonetheless, the Government considers that the primary role of the tax system is to raise revenue and that assistance to promote particular social outcomes is best delivered through direct outlay programs.

The 2010 Australia's Future Tax System Review considered options for taxing unhealthy or 'junk' foods to create an incentive for consuming fresh, healthy food. The review found that, while obesity involves significant health and productivity costs, the relationship between these costs and the consumption of particular products is complex. The risk of obesity is affected by lifestyle, such as diet and physical activity, as well as inherited and social influences. This makes it difficult to estimate spillover costs, if any, of identifiable foods or food types. In addition, any quantifiable health benefits of introducing such a tax would need to be weighed against the loss to those people who are at low risk.

The review noted that while prices and taxes influence aggregate patterns of consumption, potentially improving the wellbeing of some, they are not well suited to dealing with some forms of human behaviour and can have adverse, unintended consequences. The impact may often fall on the most vulnerable members of the community for whom direct and personal intervention, rather than population-level treatment, is more appropriate.

Obesity and poor diets are complex public health issues with multiple contributing factors. These issues require a community-wide approach as well as behaviour change by individuals. The Government is taking a multi-factorial approach to obesity prevention and nutrition promotion. Current activities in this area include:

the Health Star Rating, which helps guide consumers to make healthier choices when choosing packaged foods at the supermarket and encourages the food industry to reformulate their products to be healthier;
the new Healthy Food Partnership, which aims to increase people's health knowledge and support them to make healthier food and drink choices in order to achieve better health outcomes;
the Healthy Weight Guide website, which provides useful advice including tips and tools to encourage physical activity and healthy eating to achieve and maintain a healthy weight; and
the physical activity campaign for girls and young women, Girls Make Your Move, about the benefits of sport and physical activity in everyday health and well-being.
from the Minister for Revenue and Financial Services, Ms O'Dwyer

Thank you for your correspondence of 4 October 2017 concerning petition number EN0216 seeking that there be the option to have childcare costs deducted from the pre-tax salary of families earning $120,000 or less.

The general deductibility provisions in the tax law provide for individuals to claim deductions for losses or outgoings to the extent that they are directly incurred in gaining or producing assessable income. Child care expenses are not deductible against taxable income as these expenses are considered to be private in nature. Expenses of a private nature are not linked to assessable income and would therefore not qualify as deductions for income tax purposes.

However, employers may allow employees to salary sacrifice the cost of their child care, or child care may be provided by the employer as part of a remuneration package. Such employer provided benefits are generally subject to fringe benefits tax (FBT) payable at the top marginal tax rate plus Medicare levy. However, an FBT exemption applies to child care facilities provided on an employer's business premises.

Allowing tax deductions for child care expenses or expanding the current FBT child care exemption to all child care facilities would not be the most effective way to assist families on low to middle incomes. In particular, both tax deductions and the FBT exemption are regressive in nature, as high income earners generally receive a greater benefit than lower income earners who pay income tax at lower marginal rates or may not pay tax at all if they earn below the tax-free threshold. Allowing tax deductions for child care would also be inconsistent with established tax deductibility principles.

A direct government subsidy ensures more equitable and targeted support to low and middle income families in meeting the costs of child care. That is why the Government has delivered on its commitment to provide more affordable and more accessible child care through the recently legislated Jobs for Families Child Care Package. From 2 July 2018, the Child Care Subsidy will help those who need it most by providing more support to low and middle income families.

The package legislated in March 2017 is fundamentally fair — it will provide the greatest hours of support in child care to the families who work the longest hours, and the greatest subsidy and financial support to the families who earn the least. The Government will deliver the highest rate of subsidy to those who most need it. A family on $60,000 a year (whose child care centre charges $100 per day) would pay around $15 a day per child for care. It targets support to families who most depend upon child care in order to work, or work more.

The Government's child care package strikes the right balance between targeted child care support for hard working families who depend upon it, a generous safety net to protect those most vulnerable in our community and ongoing support for high quality early learning, which is further boosted through our $840 million in Federal support for 600 hours of universal preschool access a year. per child, in the year before school.

We want Australian families to choose their child care around their work, rather than limit their work hours to suit their child care. It is estimated that the package will encourage more than 230,000 families to increase their involvement in paid employment.
Thank you once again for writing. I trust this information will be of assistance.

Thank you for your letter of 16 August 2017 drawing my attention to petition number EN0226 on higher education reform, in particular on proposed changes to eligibility of Commonwealth supported places (CSP) affecting Australian permanent residents and New Zealand citizens.

Under current arrangements, most Australian permanent residents and most New Zealand citizens receive the same public subsidy as domestic students in CSP but they are not eligible for student loans under the Higher Education Loan Program (HELP). This means these students are required to pay their student contribution amount upfront, which can present a significant financial barrier to accessing higher education.

The Australian Government announced a proposal to extend eligibility of HELP loans to Australian permanent residents and New Zealand citizens and, in return, remove access to CSPs. Essentially, instead of paying upfront fees, eligible students would be able to defer payment of their fees through a HELP loan. The provision of an income contingent loan is a significant taxpayer investment in these students and ensures they do not face upfront barriers to study.

The Government will retain special arrangements for all Permanent Humanitarian Visa holders and New Zealand Special Category Visa holders who meet certain long-term residency requirements. These cohorts of students will continue to have been eligible for both a CSP and a HELP loan, on the same arrangements as Australian citizens. Further. should these students have become permanent residents during their course, their eligibility to continue accessing the CSP and HELP loan will be preserved until they complete their current course.

The Higher Education Support Amendment (A More Sustainable, Responsive and Transparent Higher Education System) Bill 2017 (Reform Bill) was examined by the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Human Rights, the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, and the Education and Employment Legislation Committee.

The Human Rights Committee acknowledged that 'granting access to HELP loans may pursue the legitimate objective of expanding access to higher education for New Zealand citizens and Australian permanent residents' in its examination of the Reform Bill.
from the Minister for Education and Training, Senator Birmingham
I refer to your letter concerning the petition presented to the House of Representatives' Standing Committee on Petitions (EN0238), calling for a nation-wide ban on plastic bags.

Management and regulation of waste in Australia, including plastic bags, is primarily the responsibility of state and territory governments. The Australian Government's principle role is to ensure that Australia is able to meet its obligations to a number of international agreements that apply to waste.

Work on plastic bags is coordinated nationally through the Meeting of Environment Ministers. Since 2007, ministers have endorsed the use of alternatives to plastic bags and worked with Standards Australia to develop standards for biodegradable plastic. In July 2017, ministers agreed to work with retailers to explore options to reduce the use of thicker plastic shopping bags, potentially under a voluntary code of practice.

Australia has bans on some types of plastic shopping bags in four jurisdictions — South Australia, Tasmania, the Northern Territory and the Australian Capital Territory. Both the Victorian and Queensland Governments recently committed to a ban.

The Australian Government takes marine debris and its impact on the environment and wildlife seriously, and works with other governments to address the issue of ocean pollution. The Australian Government has a Threat Abatement Plan for the Impacts of Marine Debris on Vertebrate Marine Life, which prevents waste from entering the oceans by supporting activities to reduce waste, increase recycling and monitor marine debris, including plastics.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Environment and Energy, Mr Frydenberg

The Australian Government (the Government) is working with state and territory governments to reduce air pollution and ensure a clean air future. In December 2015, Australia's environment ministers established the National Clean Air Agreement to help governments prioritise actions to improve air quality. The Government is also taking steps to reduce vehicle emissions through a review of Australia's on-road vehicle emissions standards and fuel quality standards.

Under the National Clean Air Agreement, ministers have strengthened the national ambient air quality reporting standards for airborne fine particles. The new national standards are stronger than the current World Health Organization Guidelines and aim to achieve a higher level of health protection. The Australian Government has introduced the Product Emissions Standards Act 2017. This legislation will improve Australia's air quality by setting air pollutant emission standards for specified products. The first standards will be for small petrol engines such as lawn mowers, leaf blowers and outboard motors. These engines are high emitters of pollution relative to their size and contribute up to 10 percent of air pollution on high use days.

State and territory governments have primary responsibility for monitoring, reporting on and managing air quality in their jurisdictions. They implement measures tailored to the specific requirements of their jurisdiction. This includes management of air pollution from sources such as power generation.
More information on the National Clean Air Agreement is available at: www.environment.gov.au/national-clean-air-agreement.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
from the Minister for Environment and Energy, Mr Frydenberg

Thank you for your letter of 11 September 2017 to the Minister for Human Services, the Hon Alan Tudge MP, regarding a petition presented to the House of Representatives that requests a change in policy concerning the use of 'gross' income in child support assessments (EN0293). Your letter was referred to me as the matter falls within my portfolio responsibilities. I regret the delay in responding.

Adjusted taxable income for the last relevant financial year is generally used, rather than gross income, because this is typically the most up-to-date and accurate income information available to the Department of Human Services (DHS), and is usually a reliable measure of the parents' capacity to provide financial support for their children.

Under the child support formula, the Costs of the Children Table is used to calculate an amount of child support payable for child support assessment purposes. The Costs of the Children Table was the result of extensive research into how much parents spend on children at different income levels. More information about the research can be found in the publication In the Best Interests of Children — Reforming the Child Support Scheme, available at www.dss.gov.au/our-responsibilities/families-and-children/publications-articles.

The income figures in the Costs of the Children Table are based on parents' Adjusted Taxable Income, which comprises taxable income and certain supplementary amounts such as foreign income, reportable fringe benefits, tax-free pensions and benefits, total net investment losses and reportable superannuation contributions. The inclusion of supplementary amounts ensures that child support is calculated according to parents' capacity to provide support for their children, regardless of how their income is structured.
I trust this information is of assistance and thank you again for writing. Yours sincere
from the Minister for Social Services, Mr Porter
I refer to your letter dated 11 September 2017 in relation to petition EN0300, which requests that the House of Representatives formulate a national Legal Aid Act.
Legal Aid is administered by the States and Territories.
The Commonwealth contributes substantial funds to assist in providing legal aid to vulnerable people. However, funding for legal aid commissions is not a matter for the Australian Government alone.
There are currently eight legal aid commissions - one in each state and territory. Legal aid commissions are independent statutory bodies established under state and territory legislation.

Commonwealth funding for legal aid commissions is administered by states and territories under the National Partnership Agreement on Legal Assistance Services 2015-2020 (the Agreement). From 2015-2020, the Australian Government is providing over $1.7 billion to legal aid commissions, community legal centres, and Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Legal Services, to deliver legal assistance services to people experiencing financial disadvantage.

The Agreement recognises the discretion legal aid commissions have to determine their own eligibility thresholds. This allows eligibility thresholds to be tailored to account for varying factors in each jurisdiction. Neither 1, nor the Attorney-General's Department, can intervene in or influence individual decisions made by a legal aid commission. All legal aid commissions have complaints processes that allow a person to lodge a complaint if they are not satisfied with the outcome of their application for legal aid or the actions or conduct of their legal aid lawyer.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before the Parliament.

Thank you for your letter of 11 September 2017 concerning petition number EN302 which requests intervention to allow non-Commonwealth Register of Institutions and Courses for Overseas Students providers to deliver short courses to international students.

The Australian Government supports international students to have an outstanding living and learning experience while they are in Australia. This is reflected in the Government's commitment to the National Strategy of International Education 2025 to deliver the best possible international student experience. In addition. the Education Services for Overseas Students Act 2000 (ESOS Act) provides consumer protections to international students and ensures the education and training they undertake meets clear quality benchmarks.

International students can work up to 40 hours per fortnight whilst their course is in session and unlimited hours during scheduled course breaks. The opportunity to work while studying enhances international students" experience in Australia and supports their professional development. I understand that international students may which to undertake a range of short courses to broaden their employment opportunities in Australia whilst they study, including First Aid, Responsible Services of Alcohol and Security Operations.

The ESOS Act does not intend to restrict international students from undertaking short courses while in Australia. The Department of Education and Training is working to address this issue and identify possible solutions, such as legislative changes, which would allow short courses to be delivered to international students. I will write to you again after I have considered the range of complex policy issues and resolved this matter.
Thank you for bringing this to my attention.
from the Assistant Minister for Vocational Education and Skills, Mr Keenan

Thank you for your letter of 20 September 2017 regarding a petition for cystic fibrosis sufferers to automatically receive a Health Care Card (HCC). I am pleased to provide some information to the Committee to assist with its work.

The Australian Government provides a variety of support for people with severe medical conditions in recognition of the significant financial and emotional demands these conditions may place on individuals and their families. These supports include Commonwealth concession cards, subsidised medical care, discounted pharmaceuticals and income support payments, where applicable.

As you are aware, under social security law, access to benefits including concession cards is determined on the basis of financial need, rather than on the basis of a medical condition. Targeting assistance towards those who are in financial need is the most equitable and cost effective approach for achieving social welfare outcomes.

Providing concession cards solely on the basis of a person's medical condition would mean that people who are financially able to cater for their needs will receive public support. It would also mean that the Government would need to determine which medical conditions would qualify for such benefits and which ones would not. On the other hand, providing people with assistance based on their financial need, as is the current approach, is equitable and less complex to administer.

Under the current approach of targeted assistance, cystic fibrosis sufferers on relatively low incomes may be eligible for a variety of payments and benefits, including a range of income support payments, related supplementary payments and access to appropriate Commonwealth concession cards that provide discounted prices for medical services and prescription drugs. Concession cards include the Pensioner Concession Card (PCC) for all pensioners, the HCC which is generally for social security allowees and the Low-Income Health Care Card (LIC) for people on a low income.

Payments that are targeted to people who are temporarily or permanently incapacitated or those caring for others, such as the Disability Support Pension, Sickness Allowance or Carer Payment and Carer Allowance, are generally linked to a concession card.

In order to be eligible for a concession card, a person generally needs to qualify for a Centrelink payment that attracts a concession card. For example, where a child under 16 years of age suffers from cystic fibrosis, their parent may receive the non-means tested Carer Allowance on their behalf, which then entitles the child to a concession card. The concession card is issued in the name of the child in recognition that the child may have higher medical costs than a child without disability or a severe medical condition.

Where a person suffering from cystic fibrosis is not receiving an income support payment, they could claim a LIC. The LIC is available to people with a low income, determined by the application of an income test of their gross income for the eight weeks immediately before they make a claim for a card. In 2017, the income limit for a single person is $546 a week. For a couple combined with no children and for a single person with one dependent child, the income limit is $943 a week.
The Government also provides assistance with medical costs and the cost of prescriptions by way of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) Safety Net and the Extended Medicare Safety Net.

The PBS Safety Net is designed to assist those people who require a large number of PBS prescriptions over a calendar year. In 2017, those who do not have a concession card need to pay up to $38.80 towards their PBS prescriptions. Once they reach the safety net threshold of $1,494.90, further PBS prescriptions are usually purchased at the current concessional co-payment rate of $6.30 per prescription.

The Extended Medicare Safety Net provides additional Medicare benefits for families and singles who have out-of-pocket costs for Medicare eligible out-of-hospital services once an annual threshold has been met. In 2017, the annual threshold for those who do not have a concession card is $2,056.30.

People who suffer from chronic diseases such as cystic fibrosis face the prospect of high medical expenses during their lifetime. The Government continues to work with healthcare organisations such as the Australian Medical Association to identify new ways to support Australians who require lifelong medical assistance. However, any consideration of extending services and supports needs to take into account budgetary pressures and community expectations.
Thank you again for bringing this petition to my attention.
from the Minister for Social Services, Mr Porter
I refer to your letter dated 11 September 2017 in relation to petition EN0311, which requests that:
the Marriage Act 1961 and the Family Law Act 1975 be amended to allow same-sex couples who married in an overseas jurisdiction to divorce under Australian law if the marriage has ended, and
the Family Law Act be amended to allow any person who is legally married under the laws of an overseas jurisdiction to access Australia's divorce system.

As you would be aware, on 7 December 2017, the Australian Parliament passed the Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Act 2017 (the Act). The Act, which commenced on 9 December 2017, provides for marriage equality in Australia by amending the Marriage Act 1961 (Cth) to redefine marriage as 'the union of 2 people to the exclusion of all others, voluntarily entered into for life'. The Act also enables recognition of foreign same-sex marriages solemnised prior to commencement of the Act.

From 9 December 2017, same-sex couples who were married overseas are recognised as legally married under Australian law, and have access to the Australian divorce system, as requested by the petitioners.

Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before Parliament, and I look forward to engaging with the Committee again in the future.
Thank you for your letter of 11 September 2017 drawing my attention to petition number EN0313 relating to staffing and courses at La Trobe University.

Universities are subject to a standards based quality system that permits academic autonomy while also ensuring protections for students and the taxpayer. While the Australian Government provides significant funding to universities for teaching and research, universities are responsible for determining their own priorities for course delivery, so long as this is in accordance with the Higher Education Standards.
I note that the petition claims La Trobe University cancelled classes based on 'funding cuts'.

Base funding for Commonwealth supported places at La Trobe has increased from $228.9 million in 2009 to a projected $396.4 million in 2017, an increase of 73.2 per cent. Under the Government's proposed reforms, between 2017 and 2021 this is expected to increase by a further 30 per cent to $516 million.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust that this information is useful.
from the Minister for Education and Training, Senator Birmingham
I refer to your letter concerning petition EN0314 presented to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Petitions regarding the phase out of leaded fuel for racing vehicles.

Lead has long being recognised for its negative health effects. It is a highly toxic, persistent poison that affects almost every organ and system in the body, especially the brain. Australia has been moving away from leaded fuels for a number of decades, with a ban on the supply of leaded fuel implemented in 2002. Since then, temporary approvals to supply leaded racing fuel for use in motorsport activities have been granted under the Fuel Quality Standards Act 2000.

The motorsport industry was first advised in 2012 that the temporary approvals were under review. In 2015, industry representatives were advised that consideration would be given to phasing out leaded racing fuel, including aviation gasoline (avgas) where it is used in racing vehicles. The proposed phase-out followed advice from the Fuel Standards Consultative Committee and the National Health and Medical Research Council regarding the adverse health effects of even small levels of lead in blood.

Throughout 2016 and early 2017, drag and other racing associations, historic vehicle associations and fuel suppliers were consulted on a phase-out of leaded racing fuel. Most stakeholders consulted found a two-year phase-out period acceptable, and preferred it over an immediate ban or a phase-out over a longer period.

After careful consideration of stakeholder views, a two-year phase-out period began on 1 July 2017, with no more leaded racing fuel permitted from 1 July 2019. A phase-out period allows time for developing unleaded racing fuels, modifying engines and changing racing categories to allow unleaded racing fuels. The Department of the Environment and Energy is working with racing fuel suppliers and motor racing and historic vehicle associations during the phase-out period to work through any implementation issues.

During the two-year phase-out period, racing fuel suppliers can continue to supply leaded racing fuels, including avgas, and unleaded racing fuels for which they have approval. From 1 July 2019, only unleaded racing fuels will be able to be supplied for use in motorsport. Lead is the only substance that is being phased out in racing fuel.
Thank you for the opportunity to respond to this petition.
from the Minister for Environment and Energy, Mr Frydenberg

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2017 concerning a petition to divert revenue from the goods and services tax (GST) attributable to feminine hygiene products to areas relating to women's health.

The Government understands that the application of the GST to feminine hygiene products is an important issue to many people. The GST is a broad-based indirect tax that replaced a number of taxes, including the wholesale sales tax. The GST applies broadly to goods and services with a limited number of exemptions in areas such as food, education and medical services. Some goods and services are GST-free because imposing GST would be technically difficult or would create inequities between private and public sector providers. Other reductions in the GST base were made to achieve the support of the Senate.

The GST is levied by the Australian Government on behalf of the states and territories. Revenue from the GST is paid to the states and territories and provides them with a secure source of revenue to fund essential community services, such as health, education and support for pensioners. Under the Intergovernmental Agreement on Federal Financial Relations and Commonwealth legislation, a change to the rate or base of the GST would need to be supported by all of the states and territories. It would also require the passage of relevant legislation by both Houses of the Commonwealth Parliament.

The Government undertook to raise the issue of the application of the GST to feminine hygiene products with the states and territories and to seek their views on the matter. At the Council on Federal Financial Relations Tax Reform Workshop on 21 August 2015. the states and territories considered a proposal to remove the GST from feminine hygiene products. As there was no unanimous agreement at that time, no change to the existing GST arrangements for feminine hygiene products will be progressed.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.

I refer to your letter dated 1 October 2017 in relation to petition EN0319, which requests that the Australian Parliament not go ahead with the Australian Marriage Law Postal Survey and, instead, hold a free vote on same-sex marriage.

As you would be aware, the Australian Bureau of Statistics conducted the Australia Marriage Law Postal Survey between 12 September and 7 November 2017. The results of the survey were announced on 15 November 2017.

Of the 79.5% of Australian voters who participated in the survey, 61.6% of respondents indicated they were in favour of same-sex marriage being legalised. This outcome delivers on the Australian Government's promise to give the Australian people an opportunity to share their views on this important issue.

The Australian Government made a commitment to facilitate the introduction of a private members Bill into the Parliament to change the definition of marriage in the event of a 'yes' result. On 15 November 2017, the Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Bill 2017 was introduced into Parliament. As I have publicly stated, I would like to see this Bill, with whatever amendments the Senate and the House of Representatives may agree to, passed before Parliament rises in December 2017.

Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. l appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before Parliament, and I look forward to engaging with the Committee again in the future.

I refer to your letter dated 16 October 2017 in relation to petition EN0320, which requests that the Australian Parliament consider and pass a motion enabling marriage equality and desist from any form of plebiscite.

As you would be aware, the Australian Bureau of Statistics conducted the Australia Marriage Law Postal Survey between 12 September and 7 November 2017. The results of the survey were announced on 15 November 2017.

Of the 79.5% of Australian voters who participated in the survey, 61.6% of respondents indicated they were in favour of same-sex marriage being legalised. This outcome delivers on the Government's promise to give the Australian people an opportunity to share their views on this important issue.

The Government made a commitment to facilitate the introduction of a private members Bill into the Parliament to change the definition of marriage in the event of a 'yes' result. On 15 November 2017, the Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Bill 2017 was introduced into Parliament. That Bill, with technical and transitional amendments, was passed by the Senate on 29 November 2017. As I have publicly stated, 1 would like to see this Bill passed as soon as reasonably possible. before Parliament rises in mid-December 2017.

Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before Parliament, and I look forward to engaging with the Committee again in the future.

Thank you for your letter of 19 October 2017 regarding a petition calling for changes to telecommunications carrier powers and immunities, submitted to the House of Representatives by the Member for Cook.

The Australian Government appreciates that people sometimes have concerns about the rollout of telecommunications infrastructure. These concerns need to be balanced against the community's need for modern communications services.

Facilities are sited to optimise their operation. Network design, including the placement of base stations and towers, is influenced by a range of factors including commercial demand, geography of the area and availability of suitable sites. The Government encourages carriers to consider co-locating their facilities where it is feasible to do so, to limit the number of towers and structures being constructed.

Telecommunications carriers have some powers and immunities under Schedule 3 to the Telecommunications Act 1997 (the Act) to undertake inspections and to install and maintain facilities. These powers primarily relate to low-impact facilities which are specified in the Telecommunications (Low-impact Facilities) Determination 1997 (LIFD).

The types of facilities that are listed as low-impact are those considered to be essential to the effective and efficient operation of telecommunications networks in providing services to the public and unlikely to cause significant disruption to the community during installation or operation. Some examples of low-impact facilities include cabinets and antennae used to deliver mobile communications services to the community.

The specification of low-impact facilities encourages carriers to roll out networks using components that fall within strict type, size, colour and location limitations, thereby minimising the impact of telecommunications infrastructure on the community generally while expediting the supply of services,

In exercising their powers and immunities, carriers must adhere to strict requirements, including a requirement to provide landowners and occupiers with notice before entering land. In addition to the conditions in the Act, the Telecommunications Code of Practice 1997 (Code of Practice) sets out further obligations on carriers. For example, under the Code of Practice, carriers must comply with good engineering practice and consider noise limits, the environment, and obstruction of essential services when installing or maintaining facilities.

Telecommunications carriers installing low-impact facilities for mobile phone networks are also required to comply with the Industry Code for Mobile Phone Base Station Deployment C564:2011 (the Industry Code). The Industry Code was developed by the Communications Alliance, and is registered with the Australian Communications and Media Authority. It sets out additional processes that carriers are to follow when installing radiocommunications facilities, including requirements for local government and community consultation. The consultation requirements in the Industry Code apply to the installation of mobile phone radiocommunications infrastructure that does not require development approval.

Approval for the installation of some telecommunications facilities is subject to state and territory planning laws. In NSW, the State Environmental Planning Policy (Infrastructure) 2007 (NSW) (SEPPI) applies to the installation of some types of mobile base stations, including some towers and monopoles. Carriers are required to follow the processes set out in the planning scheme, as well as the consultation requirements under the Industry Code for installations that do not require development approval.

The petition calls for changes to carrier powers and immunities so that mobile base stations are not installed in residential areas without approval from local governments. Removing mobile base stations installed in residential areas entirely from the powers and immunities regime could delay the rollout of mobile networks. This could result in carriers being unable to meet strong community demand for mobile services quickly and at lower cost.

As noted above, the existing framework requires local government and community consultation for such installations, allowing for concerns to be considered and addressed on a case-by-case basis. The Australian Government considers that the existing arrangements appropriately balance the need to deploy networks efficiently and at lower cost with the community's expectation that it can comment on where and how carrier facilities are located.

I understand that the catalyst for the petition was the proposed installation by Vodafone and Optus of a mobile base station at Gymea Bay, NSW. The installation at Gymea Bay was proposed to be completed using both carrier powers and immunities, and the SEPPI.

The proposed installation of the antennae and cabling on the power pole at Gymea Bay, which I understand is of most concern to the originator of the petition, was proposed to be installed as an exempt development under SEPPI. Even if the Commonwealth amended carrier powers and immunities in the way proposed, SEPPI would still apply to installations such as that proposed at Gymea Bay.

I believe, however, that the proposed installation at Gymea Bay provides an example of the current framework operating effectively. Following concerns expressed by the community and Sutherland Shire Council about the proposal through the community consultation process, I have been advised that on 16 November 2017, Vodafone and Optus submitted to Council a design for a facility at an alternative location identified by Council. Council replied in early December, and requested that a Development Approval be submitted for their consideration. The carriers are currently preparing all required information to Council for their consent as landowner, and Council will consider this at their next meeting on 19th February 2018.

Should the Council provide owner's consent, carriers will then be in a position to prepare required documentation to meet Council's requirements for a Development Application at the alternate location. Irrespective of any decision by Council about the new design, the carriers remain committed to working with Council to ensure there is a suitable outcome.
The petition has raised concerns about possible health effects from exposure to electromagnetic energy (EME) coming from mobile base stations in residential areas.

The Australian Radiation Protection and Nuclear Safety Agency (ARPANSA) is the Government agency responsible for setting the exposure standard for radiofrequency (RF) EME. The ARPANSA exposure limits are set well below the level at which adverse health effects are known to occur and include a wide safety margin to protect the public. Typically mobile phone base stations operate at a small percentage of the ARPANSA standard.

Before a mobile phone base station is built, a report is produced that shows the predicted maximum levels of EME at ground level around the new facility. It should be noted that predicted EME levels are for a base station operating at its highest capacity and assumes that all transmitters are working at full rated power. In reality base stations typically operate below full rated power levels. Reports are prepared in accordance with the ARPANSA prediction methodology and presented in an approved ARPANSA environmental EME report format.

The effects of RF EME exposure have been, and continue to be, the subject of extensive and rigorous scientific study around the world. It is the assessment of ARPANSA and other leading health authorities such as the World Health Organization that there are no known health effects at low RF EME levels, such as those emitted by mobile phone base stations. ARPANSA maintains continual oversight of emerging research into the potential health effects of RF EME emissions. If credible scientific evidence ever indicates that the current ARPANSA standard does not adequately protect the health of Australians, the Government would take immediate action to rectify the situation.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust the information will be of assistance.
from the Minister for Communications, Mr Fifield

I refer to your letter dated 16 October 2017 in relation to petition EN0331, which requests that the Australian Government abandon its promise of a plebiscite and allow a free vote on same-sex marriage.

As you would be aware, the Australian Bureau of Statistics conducted the Australia Marriage Law Postal Survey between 12 September and 7 November 2017. The results of the survey were announced on 15 November 2017.

Of the 79.5% of Australian voters who participated in the survey, 61.6% of respondents indicated they were in favour of same-sex marriage being legalised. This outcome delivers on the Government's promise to give the Australian people an opportunity to share their views on this important issue.

The Government made a commitment to facilitate the introduction of a private members Bill into the Parliament to change the definition of marriage in the event of a 'yes' result. On 15 November 2017, the Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Bill 2017 was introduced into Parliament. That Bill, with technical and transitional amendments, was passed by the Senate on 29 November 2017. As I have publicly stated, I would like to see this Bill passed as soon as reasonably possible, before Parliament rises in mid-December 2017.

Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before Parliament and I look forward to engaging with the Committee again in the future.

Thank you for your letter to the Special Minister of State, Senator the Hon Scott Ryan, concerning petition EN0334. The petition, which was presented on 16 October 2017, requested the removal of Barnaby Joyce and a by-election for the seat of New England on the grounds that Mr Joyce was 'disqualified' under s 44(i) of the Constitution. Your letter has been forwarded to me for reply as I have responsibility for the matters raised by the petition.

As the Committee would be aware, on 27 October 2017 the High Court sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns determined that, by reason of s 44(i) of the Constitution, the place of the Member for New England, the Hon Barnaby Joyce MP, is vacant, and that there should be a by-election for the election of the Member for New England. That by-election has now been scheduled for Saturday, 2 December 2017.
As the request outlined in the petition has been superseded by recent events, it would not be appropriate to comment further on the matter.
Thank you again for writing on this matter.
Thank you for your letter of 16 October 2017, requesting a response to petition EN0335 relating to the removal of the daily prayer from the House of Representatives standing orders.

The requirement for a prayer to commence proceedings, and the exact form of the words used, are set out in standing orders and therefore open to amendment by the House if it wishes. The issue of commencement with prayers has been examined on a number of occasions and changes have not been supported, perhaps reflecting the tendency of Parliaments to be traditional institutions.

The form of prayers has not changed since 1901 except for some additional words that were introduced in 1918 for the duration of the war. In 2010 the House agreed to add an acknowledgement of country at the start of sitting days, but did not change the form of the prayer.

Ultimately, as you know, responsibility for the operations of the House rests with the Members themselves, and any changes to the standing orders can only be approved with the support of a majority of Members.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.

I refer to your let November 2017 regarding Petition Number EN0336, to introduce direct billing plus co-payment arrangements for General Practitioners (GPs) and specialists' visits, which has recently been presented in the House of Representatives for consideration. 1 regret the delay in responding.

All Australians should have access to affordable quality health care regardless of where they live. 1 note the concerns raised in the petition regarding the financial burden that can be placed on members of the community who cannot access bulk billing arrangements, particularly in regional Australia, and the suggestions for addressing this issue.

Medicare benefits subsidise the cost of a professional service provided by health professionals. If a practitioner bulk bills for a service, the practitioner undertakes to accept the relevant Medicare benefit as full payment for the service. This is consistent with the operation of the Health Insurance Act 1973 (the Act) which applies to all practitioners who use Medicare. In the case of patient billed services, the patient pays the provider fee and receives the relevant Medicare rebate. Medicare is a universal scheme and does not allow exceptions for individual circumstances.

In regard to the petition request to allow providers to charge a co-payment and receive the Medicare rebate directly, a Senate inquiry into Medicare has previously considered this option and concluded that such an arrangement may have an inflationary effect on provider fees.

There are options available for patients who cannot afford to pay the full medical cost at the time of service; provided the medical practice offers these billing options. Under Pay Doctor via Claimant (PDVC), a patient can pay the provider the difference between the provider's fee and the Medicare benefit. The patient is then sent a cheque for the benefit, which the patient can forward to the provider for payment of the service. PDVC arrangements serve an important role in assisting those patients who are unable to pay for their Medicare subsidised service up-front.

I note the comment about the lack of access to bulk billing in regional Australia. To encourage doctors to bulk bill patients who may find it more difficult to pay a private fee, the Medicare Benefits Scheme (MBS) provides additional incentives for GPs treating patients who are Commonwealth Concession Card and children under 16 years of age. The current incentives are $6.25 per bulk billed service in metropolitan areas and $9.35 for services provided in rural and regional areas.

In the first quarter (July to September) of the 2017-18 financial year, patients received 80.9 million (85.9 per cent) bulk billed Medicare services compared to 76.6 million (85.4 per cent) during the same period in 2015-16. This represents an additional 4.2 million fully subsidised Medicare services compared to the same period in 2015-16.

Medical practitioners are encouraged to consider their patients' personal circumstances when determining their fees. Whilst bulk billing is available to every GP, it is their individual decision whether they choose to provide bulk billed services. It is also important for people experiencing financial hardship to discuss their personal situation with their GP or specialist who may be in a position to provide bulk billed services or reduce their fees on a case-by-case basis.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt

I refer to your letter dated 16 October 2017 in relation to petition EN0337, which requests that the Australian Parliament repeal the Marriage Amendment Act 2004. which inserted the current definition of marriage into the Marriage Act 1961.

As you would be aware, the Australian Bureau of Statistics conducted the Australia Marriage Law Postal Survey between 12 September and 7 November 2017. The results of the survey were announced on 15 November 2017.

Of the 79.5% of Australian voters who participated in the survey, 61.6% of respondents indicated they were in favour of same-sex marriage being legalised. This outcome delivers on the Government's promise to give the Australian people an opportunity to share their views on this important issue.

The Government made a commitment to facilitate the introduction of a private members Bill into the Parliament to change the definition of marriage in the event of a 'yes' result. On 15 November 2017. the Marriage Amendment (Definition and Religious Freedoms) Bill 2017 was introduced into Parliament. That Bill, with technical and transitional amendments, was passed by the Senate on 29 November 2017. As I have publicly stated, I would like to see this Bill passed as soon as reasonably possible, before Parliament rises in mid-December 2017.

Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. 1 appreciate the important work of the Standing Committee on Petitions in putting community concerns before Parliament. and I look forward to engaging with the Committee again in the future.

Thank you for your letter off 16 October 2017 in relation to petition EN0339, which calls for questions concerning the eligibility of the Member for Chisholm, Ms Julia Banks MP, to be referred to the High Court sitting as the Court of Disputed Returns.

Questions of eligibility are a matter for the House in which the eligibility question arises. Accordingly, it would not be appropriate for me to make any comment on the application of constitutional eligibility criteria to particular parliamentarians.
Thank you again for writing on this matter.1

I refer to your letter of ember 2017 concerning Petition (EN0345) - to legislate to limit the average annual increase of private health insurance premiums and to ensure that private health insurers provide information to their customers about arrangements between insurers, hospitals and medical practitioners.
In respect of legislating to limit the average annual increase in premiums, there are many variables driving increased premiums which are independent of the legislated approval process, including:
Changes in the number of persons covered
People upgrading and downgrading their policies
The type of policies that new members are purchasing
Changes to waiting periods, changes in benefits on products
Changes to prostheses pricing (and utilisation of services)
Increased compliance mechanisms to capture unnecessary admissions/readmissions
Technology change which tends to result in new higher cost treatments

Insurers use actuaries to forecast benefits and to determine the necessary premium increase required to meet their organisation's needs, including benefit outlays, reserve requirements, risks and shareholder returns.

Legally, any Director of any Australian company must have an understanding of the financial health of their organisation; particularly an awareness of their duty to prevent insolvent trading. Directors should fully appreciate the financial implications of any proposed strategies, including premium changes, and associated risks. Ultimately, external Government action to prevent insurers from generating income could enhance the risk of the financial collapse of individual private health insurers.

Setting a legislated 'limit' on premium changes could provide an incentive for insurers to set increases higher than needed and potentially stifle innovation and competition within the sector. It is not in insurers' long term interests to increase premiums without justification because higher prices (premiums) mean they are less competitive, and that undermines an insurer's viability as well as the viability of the industry as a whole.

Notwithstanding the above, applications from private health insurers for their premium increases are carefully scrutinised by the independent prudential regulator, the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority and my Department. In assessing the submissions I ensure that, in the public interest, any increases are the minimum necessary to ensure the affordability and value of private health insurance. Each insurer's application is assessed on its own merits taking into account the affordability and value of private health insurance as a product, insurer solvency requirements, forecast benefit outlays and prudential standards.

From 1 April 2017, the national industry average weighted private health insurance premium increase was 4.84 per cent. This is the lowest increase in ten years. The national industry average increase is, as the term indicates, the average increase across numerous products which have over 50,000 price points. Some people will face increases close to the average however some people will experience a wider range of increases. It is the legislated responsibility of insurers to inform their members of the exact premium increase for their particular policy.

In respect of the comment around 'premium increases are discriminating on age and location ignoring extensive periods without claims', the Private Health Insurance Act 2007 requires Australian private health insurers to offer community-rated health insurance. Community rating ensures that the premium paid by consumers for a private health insurance policy does not vary based on age or health status. If private health insurance was risk-rated, the elderly, sick, disabled and those who engage in activities that might risk their good health could be refused cover or would likely pay extremely high premiums, making private health insurance unaffordable and placing a higher cost to the public health system.

In relation to 'gifts' or incentives, my Department is aware that some health insurers are working innovatively to attract and retain members, and to avoid the costs associated with turnover of customers in the health insurance market. This includes providing inducements to members, particularly those that may not see much ongoing value in their health insurance policies due to making low or no claims each year

Under Rule 6 of the Private Health Insurance (complying Product) Rules 2015 (the Rules) discounts can be incentive payments, promotional payments, rebates or any other inducement in respect of payment of the premium for the policy, including to induce a person to purchase or maintain a policy.

Under Rule 6 of the Rules discounts are limited to a maximum of 12 per cent of the full premium per annum with the exception of any promotion offered when a person first purchases a policy which cannot exceed 12 per cent of the full premium for a year.

Lastly, in relation to public information on which medical practitioners and which hospitals are working with each fund, I note that if patients choose a private service, Medicare will pay 75 per cent of the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) fee for medical professional services provided as part of their hospital treatment. Private health insurers are required to pay at least the remaining 25 per cent of the MBS fee for insured persons who hold the necessary private health insurance. Health insurers can choose to pay more than the required 25 per cent of the MBS fee, and most commonly do when the insurer and the practitioner have entered into a preferred provider gap cover arrangement. In these circumstances, patients will either have no gap to pay, or are informed in advance about any gap.

Preferred provider schemes have been in place for a number of years. If health insurance members choose to use one of a health insurer's preferred providers, a more attractive benefit may be offered. The schemes seek to maxirnise the benefits of private health insurance cover for members. In order to continue to maintain their preferred provider network, health insurers negotiate with General Treatment (extras) health care providers across Australia.
Insurers are responsible for communicating this information to their members, and do communicate this information if a member contacts their insurer prior to their medical procedure.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt

Thank you for your correspondence of 16 October 2017 concerning petition number EN0351, which was presented in the House of Representatives, regarding Visitor visa application approval for persons with non-contagious extra-pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the Assistant Minister for Immigration and Border Protection, as the matter raised falls within my portfolio responsibilities
TB whether pulmonary or extra-pulmonary, is the only health condition in itself prescribed in the Migration Regulations 1994 as specifically precluding the grant of a visa.

The Department of Immigration and Border Protection conducts pre-migration health screening to assess an applicant's health. Its purpose is to prevent, or limit, both the importation of threats to public health (including but not limited to TB) and to avert excessive charges to Australia's public health system.

The Communicable Disease Network of Australia reports that 90 per cent of all TB cases in Australia occur in foreign-born persons. To ensure that the Australian community remains protected, visa applicants must be free from TB (defined as infection with Mycobacterium Tuberculosis that is actively replicating) and diagnosed through clinical, radiological or pathological methods. Visa applicants with TB are not eligible for a health clearance, until completion of treatment and confirmatory testing indicates total cure. This includes both pulmonary and extra-pulmonary TB. Latent TB infection does not preclude health clearance as the legislation is interpreted as free from active TB.
I acknowledge the petition's reference to the relatively low infectiousness of extra-pulmonary TB.

TB is a complex disease that can be difficult to diagnose, and there are many management challenges. TB can affect many organ systems, and, in some cases, extra-pulmonary and pulmonary TB co-exist, or one can lead to the other. Treatment of TB is both lengthy and costly, particularly in cases of drug resistance.

Due to this complexity, comprehensive screening and subsequent adequate treatment is required, regardless of whether the TB is pulmonary or extra-pulmonary. Due to the reasons outlined above, extra-pulmonary TB and pulmonary TB cannot be differentiated for the purposes of determining if an applicant is free from TB, and this requirement cannot be waived at the Minister's discretion.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention.
from the Assistant Minister for Immigration and Border Security, Mr Hawke
Thank you for your letter of 16 October 2017 concerning petition number EN0352 on the listing of left wing hate groups as terrorist organisations.

The Criminal Code provides a strict legislative process that must be followed in order to list or proscribe an organisation as a terrorist organisation under Australian law. Before an organisation can be listed as a terrorist organisation, I must be satisfied on reasonable grounds that the organisation is directly or indirectly engaged in preparing, planning, assisting in or fostering the doing of a terrorist act, or that the organisation advocates the doing of a terrorist act. I take advice from Australian national security agencies on the case for proscribing a group as a terrorist organisation under the Criminal Code.

Each of the 25 organisations currently listed under the Criminal Code regime has been assessed as meeting the legislative criteria for listing. Further details about the Criminal Code regime can be found on the National Security website: www.nationalsecuritv.gov.au.

Where there is a basis for suspecting that the activities of an organisation are of security concern, they are investigated by the relevant authorities and appropriate action is taken. The issue of which organisations should be listed under the Criminal Code regime remains under active review by Australia's security and intelligence agencies.

The Criminal Code also contains provisions relating to treason and the prevention of terrorist financing, which form part of Australia's strong counter-terrorism and national security framework. These offences only apply where the specific elements of each offence are satisfied.
Thank you for bringing this petition to the Government's attention.

Thank you for your letter of 16 October 2017 concerning a petition requesting review and amendment to the regulatory framework for political advertising to ensure protections for the LGBTIQA+ community.
The Australian Government recognises the importance of advertisements being legal, honest and truthful and not offensive to their audience.

I note that the petitioners' requested that anti-marriage equality advertisements be banned during 2017 and, in particular, requested a House of Representatives review of the content of the Coalition for Marriage's "You Can Say No" marriage law survey advertising campaign. The content of most advertisements in Australia are subject to predominantly self-regulatory arrangements. Under this framework, self-regulatory codes of practice developed by the Australian Association of National Advertisers (AANA), the industry body for advertisers in Australia, are administered by the Advertising Standards Bureau (ASB). The ASB directs complaints to the Advertising Standards Board (the Board).

The AANA Code of Ethics (the AANA Code) is designed to reflect community values and expectations. The AANA Code is platform neutral, and applies to most advertisements, including material that is broadcast, printed, hosted online, and outdoor media displayed on billboards or posters. However, the AANA Code only relates to commercial communications, not political messaging, which falls outside the charter of the Board.

The Board's position on political advertising ensures its integrity as an impartial adjudicator, free from perceptions of political bias. Adjudications by the Board on political messaging could also unintentionally restrict the implied constitutional freedom of political communication or unduly interfere with the political process. There are also concerns that opening up the complaints handling system to political advertising could invite spurious claims and nuisance complaints that may disrupt normal political processes and the general processes of the advertising self-regulatory framework.

In relation to marriage equality advertising conducted during the marriage law survey period, the ASB confirmed in a blog post on 17 August 2017 that most marriage equality advertising, including advertisements advocating the respective 'yes' or 'no' cases, would likely be considered as political advertising and so would not be covered by the AANA Code. However, the ASB's blog post also noted that some advertisements might be referred to the Board for consideration against the AANA Code, on a case-by-case basis. The ASB's previous practice has been to refer complaints relating to the content of political advertisements only, for example complaints relating to perceived violent imagery, rather than complaints about the political message of the advertisement.
Complaints about the content of advertisements can be directed in writing to the ASB via its website, at www.adstandards.com.au for consideration by the Board.

The Board comprises members of the general community who are independent of the advertising industry and from a range of age groups and backgrounds. Further information about the Board, including information about the appointment of Board members, is available at wvvvv.adstandards.com.au/aboutus/theadvertisingstandardsboard.

Decisions of the Board may be independently reviewed and you may wish to visit the website at www.adstandards.com.au/complaint-process/independent-review to obtain further information about the review process.

The Government has no plans to amend these self-regulatory arrangements. The advertising self-regulatory framework reflects that it is ultimately advertisers that bear the primary responsibility for the content of their advertisements and therefore creates a set of principles to ensure advertising content reflects community standards and expectations.

I note that the petitioners requested that marriage equality advertisements be subject to advertising standards prohibiting vilification and discrimination against people based on sexual preference. Based on community concerns, the Parliament enacted legislative safeguards to regulate the conduct of the marriage law survey debate.
The Marriage Law Survey (Additional Safeguards) Act 2017 (the Act) commenced on

14 September 2017 and established additional safeguards to existing legislative protections, to promote and protect the expression of free and informed views on the same sex marriage survey. This included extending the same authorisation requirements to broadcasters as would have applied for elections, a key measure for achieving transparency for audiences.

The Act provided a range of offences and civil penalty provisions to safeguard against certain conduct, which ensured a fair and democratic debate about the important issue of same sex marriage. For instance, the Act made it a civil penalty, subject to a fine, to vilify, intimidate or threaten a person or a group of people based on religious views, sexual orientation, gender identity or intersex status, or based on the views a person expressed in relation to the marriage law survey question. This obligation applied to advertisements that were broadcast on behalf of both the 'yes' and 'no' campaigns. These offences and civil penalty provisions were in place from the commencement of the Act until the Act's repeal when the marriage law survey period ended with the release of the results on 15 November 2017.

I note the petitioners' request to generally prohibit misleading or deceptive political advertisements. The Australian Government believes that Australian citizens are the most appropriate arbiter of the worth of political claims.

There are currently no regulatory requirements for the content of election advertising to be factually correct. In terms of the advertising self-regulatory framework, the ASS has been consistent in ensuring the Board does not intervene on truth and accuracy issues in political advertising.

The petitioners may be interested to know that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters (the Committee) is currently tasked with considering the potential applicability of truth in advertising provisions to communications to voters as part of its wide-ranging inquiry into the conduct of the 2016 Federal Election (the Inquiry). The Committee has yet to report on such provisions. I would encourage the petitioners to follow the Inquiry and, where applicable, engage with the Committee to put forward their views on truth in political advertising provisions. More information is available from the Inquiry home page at https://www.aph.gov.au/Parliamentary_Business/Committees/Joint/Electoral_Matters/ 2016Election.
Thank you for bringing this petition to my attention. I trust this information will be of assistance.
from the Minister for Communications, Mr Fifield

Thank you for your letter of 5 December 2017 seeking a ministerial response to petition EN0378, which calls for a referendum to amend section 51 of the Constitution so that the Commonwealth may pass laws with respect to 'domestic relationships, civil unions and de facto partnerships'.

The Australian Government's priority for constitutional reform is the recognition of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, and to that end it will work with the Opposition and the cross-bench on a question that has the greatest chance of success at a referendum.
The Australian Government has no plans to put forward a referendum in the terms proposed by the petition.
Thank you again for writing on this matter.
Thank you for your letter of 5 December 2017 regarding petition number EN0396 on the detention of Mr Jock Palfreeman in Bulgaria.

The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade takes its consular role very seriously and aims to provide a high quality service to Australians in difficulty overseas. The nature and extent of this assistance is set out in the Consular Services Charter, a copy of which is enclosed for your reference.

As outlined in the Charter, there are limits to what we can do. For example, the Australian Government cannot intervene in the legal processes of another country, Just as we would not countenance another country seeking to do so in Australia. For this reason, it would also be inappropriate for the Australian Parliament to `recognise the imprisonment of Jock Palfreeman [as] unlawful' as requested in the petition.
Obligations under Australia's Privacy Act prevent the disclosure of specific information regarding Mr Palfreeman's case. However, in the time since

Mr Palfreeman's arrest, consular officials in Athens (Australia's post accredited Bulgaria), in Canberra, and in the Australian Honorary Consul in Sofia, have provided appropriate consular assistance to Mr Palfreeman and his family. This support will continue so long as Mr Palfreeman remains in Bulgaria.
I trust this information is of assistance.
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Ms Bishop
Thank you for your correspondence on petitions PN0079, PN0110, PN0152 regarding action to address climate change.

The Australian Government (the Government) is taking action on climate change and contributing to global efforts to reduce emissions. As part of the Paris Agreement, Australia has committed to reduce emissions by 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. This will see Australia's emissions per person halve and the emissions intensity of our economy reduce by two-thirds. On this basis, Australia's target is among the strongest of major economies.

Addressing the impacts of climate change is a priority for the Pacific region. Through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Government works closely with Pacific island countries and regional organisations to build resilience to the impacts of climate change. We have sustained and increased funding to sectors affected by climate change such as fisheries, and for disaster preparedness.

The Government's policies to reduce emissions are working and we will meet our international commitments. We are reducing emissions through the Emissions Reduction Fund, providing incentives to Australian businesses, communities and farmers for adopting new practices and technologies that reduce emissions. The Renewable Energy Target ensures 23.5 per cent of Australia's electricity comes from renewable sources by 2020 and the National Energy Productivity Plan is reducing emissions through more efficient use of energy. The Government is also helping households install rooftop solar panels and solar hot water systems through rebates under the Renewable Energy Target.

In addition the recently announced National Energy Guarantee (the Guarantee) will require energy retailers and some large users across the National Electricity Market to deliver reliable and lower emissions energy generation each year. The Guarantee is estimated to reduce household electricity bills by an average of $120 per year from 2020. The Government will continue to work with the independent Energy Security Board and the states through the Council of Australian Governments to implement these reforms.
Thank you for your correspondence on petitions PN0081, PN0089, PN0085, PN0083, PN0075 and PN0074 regarding action to address climate change.

The Australian Government (the Government) is taking action on climate change and contributing to global efforts to reduce emissions. The Government will continue to work with the independent Energy Security Board and the states through the Council of Australian Governments to implement these reforms.
from the Minister for Environment and Energy, Mr Frydenberg
Thank you for your correspondence on petitions PN0094. PN0097. PN0101. PN0102 regarding the harmful impacts of climate change.

The Australian Government (the Government) is taking action on climate change and contributing to global efforts to reduce emissions. As part of the Paris Agreement. Australia has committed to reduce emissions by 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. from the Minister for Environment and Energy, Mr Frydenberg
Thank you for your correspondence on petitions PN0081, PN0089, PN0085, PN0083, PN0075 and PN0074 regarding action to address climate change.

The Australian Government (the Government) is taking action on climate change and contributing to global efforts to reduce emissions. As part of the Paris Agreement, Australia has committed to reduce emissions by 26 to 28 per cent below 2005 levels by 2030. This will see Australia's emissions per person halve and the emissions intensity of our economy reduce by two-thirds. On this basis, Australia's target is among the strongest of major economies.

Through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, the Government works closely with Pacific island countries and regional organisations to build resilience to the impacts of climate change. We have sustained and increased funding to sectors affected by climate change such as fisheries, and for disaster preparedness.

from the Minister for Environment and Energy, Mr Frydenberg
I refer to your letter of September 2017 concerning Petition PN0086 - Regarding Alpha 1 Antitrypsin Deficiency (AATD).
I note the request in the petition to fast track funding arrangements for therapies for the treatment of AATD.
As referenced in the petition, there are two alpha I proteinase inhibitor products that have recently been registered on the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (ARTG) for the treatment of AATD:
the CSL Behring product ZemairaTM (registered in February 2017); and
the Grifols product Prolastin-C (registered in November 2016).

Augmentation therapies for AATD are blood-related products derived from human plasma. In Australia, there are two mechanisms by which patients can generally obtain government subsidised access to such products:
products may be supplied to patients through any approved health provider (which includes both public and private hospitals) under the national blood arrangements; or
products may be supplied to an individual patient through a hospital under arrangements put in place by the hospital or the respective jurisdictional government, or funded in some other way.

The National Blood Authority (NBA) acts on behalf of the Commonwealth and state and territory governments to administer the national blood arrangements. The policy and administrative arrangements for the national blood arrangements were agreed by all governments under the National Blood Agreement (the Agreement), with funding of the arrangements shared between the Commonwealth and the states and territories. Schedule 4 of the Agreement outlines the process for determining what products should be supplied and funded by governments under the national arrangements.
Given the joint funding arrangements, the supply of products under the national blood arrangements requires approval by all governments. The approval process requires that:
the product is listed on the ARTG;

the supply of the product has been assessed as meeting the requirements of the Agreement - this assessment is conducted against an agreed set of criteria that are primarily focussed on clinical evidence and efficacy, as well as cost; and
governments have approved funding to enable the supply of this product; if additional funding is required, governments will consider applications within the overall context of expenditure priorities.
The NBA has recently received Schedule 4 applications from both potential suppliers of Alpha-I -proteinase inhibitor products for consideration for funding under the national blood arrangements.

The assessment process for these proposals and the duration will depend on the complexity of the proposals, cost and the views of jurisdictions. As there is potentially more than one supplier, a tender might also be required following the evaluation and approval processes.

The evaluation process will require consideration by the Jurisdictional Blood Committee, with submission to the Council of Australian Governments Health Council for decision. Based on the timing for consideration of previous submissions, the timeframe for the evaluation and approval processes may take approximately 12 months.

I would like to note the potential for registered products to be supplied to individuals outside of the national arrangements. It may be possible for medical practitioners to prescribe products for medical conditions that are not funded under the national blood arrangements through a public hospital via the local hospital therapeutics committee. These local arrangements vary between hospitals and jurisdictions. Those with AATD can approach their doctors or their relevant Government regarding funding through such an arrangement.
Thank you for writing on this matter.
from the Minister for Health, Mr Hunt

I refer to your correspondence concerning the petition on the potential impact of the first large scale underground coal mine proposed by Hume Coal on the Sydney water catchment area and on the Kangaloon Aquifer underlying the Southern Highlands (PN 0098).
